stems: card
cards
in the cards
on the cards

ins.spl: plural in form but singular or plural in construction

dt: {bc}something (such as an advantage) compared to a valuable playing card in one's hand
{bc}an issue especially with emotional appeal that is brought into play to achieve a desired end (such as winning a political campaign)
{bc}a flat stiff usually small and rectangular piece of material (such as paper, {a_link|cardboard}, or plastic) usually bearing information: such as
{bc}one bearing a picture (as of a baseball player) on one side and usually statistical data on the other
{bc}one on which computer information is stored (as in the form of punched holes or magnetic encoding)
{bc}one bearing electronic circuit components for insertion into a larger electronic device (such as a computer)

dt.t: success just wasn't {it}in the cards{/it} for her

et: Middle English {it}carde{/it}, from Anglo-French, alteration of Middle French {it}carte{/it}, probably from Old Italian {it}carta{/it}, literally, leaf of paper, from Latin {it}charta{/it} leaf of papyrus, from Greek {it}chartēs{/it}

stems: card
carded
carding
cards

dt: {bc}to ask for identification (as in a bar)
{bc}to place or fasten on or by means of a card
{bc}to list or record on a card

to place or fasten on or by means of a card

dt: {bc}to cleanse, disentangle, and collect together (fibers) by the use of {d_link|cards|card:4} preparatory to spinning

dt: {bc}an instrument or machine for {d_link|carding|card:3} fibers that consists usually of bent wire teeth set closely in rows in a thick piece of leather fastened to a back
{bc}an implement for raising a nap on cloth

et: Middle English {it}carde{/it}, from Medieval Latin {it}cardus, carduus{/it}, thistle, carding instrument, from Latin {it}carduus{/it} thistle {ma}{mat|chard|}{/ma}
shortdef: an instrument or machine for carding fibers that consists usually of bent wire teeth set closely in rows in a thick piece of leather fastened to a back
an implement for raising a nap on cloth

stems: cards are stacked against
cards are stacked against (someone)
cards are stacked against someone

dt: used to describe a situation in which one person or group is disadvantaged or faces difficult circumstances as compared to others often in a way that is unfair

dt.t: In many ways, the {it}cards are stacked against{/it} immigrants.

shortdef: —used to describe a situation in which one person or group is disadvantaged or faces difficult circumstances as compared to others often in a way that is unfair

houses of cards

dt: {bc}a structure, situation, or institution that is insubstantial, shaky, or in constant danger of collapse

shortdef: a structure, situation, or institution that is insubstantial, shaky, or in constant danger of collapse

dt: {bc}to be in control of a situation and have the power to make decisions

dt.t: It's your decision. You're {it}holding all the cards{/it}.

shortdef: to be in control of a situation and have the power to make decisions

dt: {bc}to make a mistake due to the belief that one's position is stronger or better than it really is

shortdef: to make a mistake due to the belief that one's position is stronger or better than it really is
